seo.h1_title: Abruzzo's Mountain Heart: Santo Stefano, Scanno & Majella National Park
seo.intro_paragraph: Approach Civitella del Tronto and its ramparts on the ridge, then reach lakeside Scanno in a mountain setting. Cross Santo Stefano di Sessanio and its austere stones, discover Guardiagrele and its goldsmith craftsmanship, then stop at Pescocostanzo, a village suspended in Abruzzo's air. The region tells itself in relief, silence and craft.
seo.seo_hook: Fortresses crowning ochre ridges, mountain silence enveloping villages, alpine lakes with crystal reflections. Abruzzo, Italy's village heart.

seo.h1_title: Bologna's Apennine Escape: Lakes, Porretta Terme & Hidden Hill Towns
seo.intro_paragraph: Wander beneath Bologna's porticos and let kitchen aromas guide your steps, then reach Brisighella and its ochre hills. Follow Grizzana Morandi's artistic trace, breathe the air of Laghi Suviana Brasimone and reach Corno alle Scale for open panoramas. Emilia blends generous tables with wide-open spaces.
seo.seo_hook: Medieval towers punctuating the horizon, mountain terraces in ochre tones, lakes reflecting granite peaks. Bologna's natural soul.

seo.h1_title: Southern Italy Coastal Journey: Naples, Amalfi Coast & Calabrian Soul
seo.intro_paragraph: Leave Naples' bustle behind to follow the coast to Paola, then reach Tropea suspended above clear waters. Cross the strait at Villa San Giovanni, explore Scilla and its marine legends, then head inland toward Fiumefreddo. Winding roads reveal secret coves and ancient villages, unveiling southern Italy's intensity.
seo.seo_hook: Volcanoes commanding the hinterland, hilltop villages defying gravity. Naples to Calabria, Mediterranean fire.

seo.h1_title: Wild Calabria Adventure: Mountain Hikes & Turquoise Mediterranean Coasts
seo.intro_paragraph: Approach Lamezia Terme as a southern threshold, then climb toward Pizzo and its fortress facing the sea. Explore Palmi and its coastal bond, reach Gerace perched on its medieval spur, then follow Catanzaro and Amantea's peaceful beaches. In Rossano, Byzantine heritage anchors Calabria's deep soul.
seo.seo_hook: Mountains plunging into turquoise seas, medieval towns guarding cliff secrets. Calabria, wild and mysterious.

seo.h1_title: Amalfi Coast Jewel: Cliffs, Villages and Capri Magic
seo.intro_paragraph: The Amalfi Coast itinerary follows one of Italy‚Äôs most dramatic coastlines, from Salerno and Amalfi to Sorrento and Capri. Suspended villages, winding coastal roads and sea-carved cliffs define a region where geography dictates both architecture and daily life.
seo.seo_hook: Cliffs plunging into turquoise depths, villages crowning dizzying heights. Amalfi, dramatic and romantic jewel.

seo.h1_title: Amalfi Coast Village Guide: Positano, Ravello, Atrani & Path of the Gods
seo.intro_paragraph: Admire Positano cascading in color toward the sea, then gain height at Agerola above coastal mists. Wander through Amalfi between cathedral and piazza, climb toward Ravello's suspended gardens and end at Salerno, luminous anchor of the Amalfi Coast.
seo.seo_hook: Villages clinging to cliffs at impossible angles, terraced gardens cascading over stone. The Amalfi Coast, beauty suspended in eternal summer light.

seo.h1_title: Italian Dolomites Travel Guide: Hiking Emerald Lakes & Alpine Peaks
seo.intro_paragraph: Breathe Merano's spa atmosphere in the heart of South Tyrol, then gain altitude at Ortisei and in Val Gardena's alpine pastures. Contemplate Cortina d'Ampezzo's mythic silhouettes, cross Dobbiaco's alpine stillness and let turquoise lakes reflect limestone cliffs. The Dolomites unfold a powerful luminous mineral stage.
seo.seo_hook: Emerald lakes reflecting granite peaks, alpine meadows carpeted with wildflowers. The Dolomites, mountain drama and unspoiled majesty.

itineraries.title: Castles of the Piacenza Hills: A 4-Day Medieval Road Trip Through Northern Italy

visits.text: Admire Piazza Cavalli, the beating heart of Piacenza dominated by two majestic Baroque equestrian statues of Alessandro and Ranuccio Farnese. Commissioned in 1600 and crafted by Mochi da Montevarchi over 13 years of work, they represent the third and fourth Duke of Parma and Piacenza in a breathtaking masterpiece of bronze casting.

Visit the Cathedral of Santa Maria Assunta and Santa Giustina, one of the best-preserved examples of Romanesque architecture in Italy. Built between the 11th and 12th centuries, it conceals behind its sober fa√ßade a richly frescoed interior, crowned by the extraordinary dome painted by Guercino in the 17th century. Climb the 136 steps to reach the 27-meter-high dome.

Explore the Museums of Palazzo Farnese, a sumptuous period building housing seven different exhibition areas: the Picture Gallery, the Carriage Museum, the Civic Museum, the Rizzi Vaccari Collection, the Ceramics Museum, the Risorgimento Museum, and the Archaeological Museum. A journey through centuries of Piacenza's history and art.

Discover the Ricci Oddi Modern Art Gallery, a museum established in 1931 that houses the famous Portrait of a Lady by Gustav Klimt. The painting, stolen in 1997 and found over twenty years later in a hidden trapdoor within the museum itself, has been visible again since 2020 and is one of the most mysterious masterpieces in art history.

activities.text: Stroll beneath the arcades of the historic center to the Basilica of Santa Maria di Campagna, a jewel of Renaissance art with its frescoed chapel blending religious and pagan figures. Since 2024, visitors can climb to the dome to admire the details of the masterpieces from a unique perspective.

Visit the Municipal Theater, inaugurated in the early 19th century and considered among the most beautiful in Italy, as Stendhal himself proclaimed. The three-quarter ellipse auditorium, revolutionary for its time, offers extraordinary acoustics and interior decorations of meticulous elegance.

visits.text: Explore the Castle and Historic Park of Grazzano Visconti, the most precious part of this unique village. The 14th-century castle, completely restored by Giuseppe Visconti di Modrone in eclectic style, offers guided tours through the courtyard, the richly furnished reception rooms, and the bedrooms on the first floor.

Wander through the Castle Park, 15 hectares of English and Italian gardens designed by Giuseppe Visconti. Statues, vases, columns, fountains, and an extraordinary variety of trees and shrubs create a fairytale atmosphere, completed by the delightful little girls' cottage that seems straight out of a storybook.

Visit the Wax Museum with statues of figures connected to Piacenza's history, and the Torture Museum in the Palazzetto dell'Istituzione, small but complete, with torture instruments accompanied by explanatory panels. Adjacent is an Escape Room themed around the Inquisition.

Admire the Parish Church of Saints Cosmas and Damian, the oldest building in the village with 17th-century renovations. Inside, the Chapel of Our Lady of Lourdes houses numerous ex-votos, testimony to popular devotion through the centuries.

activities.text: Lose yourself in the white lanes of the village, admiring the cottages with frescoed fa√ßades, the arcades, and the statues. In the Cortevecchia you'll find the statue of Aloisa, the famous ghost of Grazzano Visconti, and a small museum of agricultural tools under the long portico.

Explore the numerous craft shops and souvenir stores, open in every season on weekends. This rare example of revivalist architecture, recognized as a City of Art by the Emilia Romagna Region in 1986, will make you feel catapulted back in time 700 years.

visits.text: Explore the Rocca Viscontea, an imposing medieval fortress built between 1342 and 1349 at the behest of Luchino Visconti of Milan. With its four square corner towers, double defensive walls, and deep moat, it represents one of the best-preserved castles in Italy. Today it houses a fascinating Museum of Medieval Life.

Admire the Palazzo del Podest√† in Piazza del Borgo, emblem of civic power built at the end of the 13th century by Alberto Scotti, lord of Piacenza. The elegant exposed brick fa√ßade dominates the village's main square, creating one of the most photographed medieval views in Emilia Romagna.

Visit the Collegiate Church of Santa Maria, a place of worship with ancient origins dating back to the 7th century. The sober Romanesque gabled fa√ßade decorated with blind arches hides naves adorned with precious 15th-century frescoes of extraordinary beauty.

Discover the Geological Museum housed in the ancient Hospital of Santo Spirito, a 13th-century building that once offered hospitality to pilgrims on the Via Francigena. The paleontological collections bear witness to millions of years of natural history in the Piacenza territory.

activities.text: Stroll through the Garden of Poetry, a large green expanse where you can find a silent refuge among evergreen trees and romantic benches. From here you can admire the entire Val d'Arda and several monuments dedicated to illustrious figures such as the luthier Antonio Stradivari.

Lose yourself in the cobblestone lanes of the village, one of the best-preserved windows onto medieval life in Italy, framed by noble palaces and Romanesque churches expressing the power of the Scotti, Visconti, and Sforza families.

visits.text: Explore the fortified village of Vigoleno, certified among the Most Beautiful Villages in Italy and Orange Flag of the Italian Touring Club. This perfect example of medieval residential logic is characterized by the elegance of its forms, with imposing crenellated walls traversed by a panoramic patrol walkway.

Climb the quadrangular keep equipped with arrow slits, machicolations, and Ghibelline merlons, with four floors of visits offering spectacular views over the surrounding countryside and hills. Inside the castle, the small theater with oriental images is a hidden gem not to be missed.

Visit the Romanesque Church of San Giorgio from the second half of the 12th century, reachable by continuing east from the main square where the 16th-century fountain stands. The intimate and spiritual atmosphere of this sacred place transports you back in time.

activities.text: Taste the Vin Santo di Vigoleno, a DOC passito wine whose vinification and aging operations must be carried out exclusively in the territory of the municipality of Vernasca. A golden nectar representing the oenological excellence of the Piacenza Hills.

Walk the Brigands' Ring, a circuit of about 21 km that starts from Vigoleno and arrives in Vernasca passing through Monte Ciocca. During flowering season, the golden broom creates an unforgettable natural spectacle.

seo.h1_title: Castles of the Piacenza Hills: A 4-Day Medieval Road Trip Through Northern Italy
seo.intro_paragraph: Embark on a journey through time in the Piacenza Hills, where imposing medieval fortresses rise above perfectly preserved fairytale villages. This 4-day itinerary takes you to discover masterpieces of Romanesque architecture, hidden artistic treasures, and vineyard landscapes of rare beauty in one of Emilia Romagna's most enchanting regions.
seo.seo_hook: An immersion into the Italian Middle Ages among castles, fairytale villages, and the wine excellence of the Piacenza Hills.
featured_list: Piacenza, city of art with Piazza Cavalli and the rediscovered Klimt
Grazzano Visconti, fairytale village recreated in medieval style
Castell'Arquato, one of the best-preserved medieval centers in Italy
Vigoleno, Orange Flag fortified village and its DOC Vin Santo

seo.h1_title: Romagna's Fortress Route: A Tour of Medieval Strongholds & Villages, Italy
seo.intro_paragraph: Travel back in time at Rimini between Roman traces and seafront, then climb toward Santarcangelo di Romagna and its hills. Cross Verucchio, approach San Leo and its fortress set upon the void, and let the Middle Ages tell their story in stone. Romagna reveals itself through viewpoints, lanes and stubborn stories.
seo.seo_hook: Medieval towers piercing rocky ridges, fortresses commanding panoramas, stone villages drowsing. Romagna's strongholds, medieval soul.

seo.h1_title: Friuli-Venezia Giulia, Italy: Roman Aquileia to Alpine Villages Tour

In Aquileia, walk among Roman traces and basilicas, before slowing down in Grado's lagoon gentleness. Lago di Cornino brings mineral breath, between limestone cliffs and calm reflections of northeast Italy.
seo.seo_hook: Imperial squares rising majestic, Roman ruins of Aquileia, lagoon villages of Grado. Northeastern Friuli in all its soul.

seo.h1_title: Latina Province & the Pontine Islands: From the Mainland to Ponza
seo.intro_paragraph: Explore Sermoneta and its imposing castle, then follow Priverno on the inland slopes. Reach Sperlonga and its sea cliffs, cross Gaeta and its harbor traditions, then reach Fondi and its fertile plain. Southern Lazio alternates sea, stone and open horizons.
seo.seo_hook: Castles crowning peaks, coastal caves guarding mythic past, fortresses keeping watch. Southern Lazio, mountain treasure.

seo.h1_title: The Castelli Romani: A Guide to the Hilltop Villages Near Rome

seo.seo_hook: Castles crowning volcanic lakes, hilltop villages buzzing with artistic life, ancient ruins terracing the slopes. Escape into the Roman countryside.

seo.h1_title: Lazio Beyond Rome: Etruscan Sites, Volcanic Lakes & Tyrrhenian Coast
seo.intro_paragraph: Admire Tivoli and Villa d'Este's cascading gardens, then return to Bracciano and its dark waters. Cross Viterbo, approach Civita di Bagnoregio and its silences, explore Tarquinia and its Etruscan treasures before following the coast toward Gaeta. Lazio reveals rare contrasting depth.
seo.seo_hook: Imperial villas cascading with water, Etruscan cities whispering their age, volcanic lakes shimmering. The grand tour of Lazio.

itineraries.title: Grand Tour of the Italian Lakes: Milan, Lakes Maggiore, Como and Verona
itineraries.subtitle: From Milan to Verona, an enchanting journey through the most beautiful lakes and art cities of northern Italy

visits.text: Let yourself be enchanted by the majestic Milan Cathedral, a masterpiece of Gothic architecture that dominates the square of the same name. With its 3,500 statues, soaring spires reaching towards the sky and the famous gilded Madonnina standing 4 metres tall, this cathedral dedicated to Santa Maria Nascente is the beating heart of the city. Climb to the terraces for a spectacular view over the metropolis and the Alps on clear days.

Walk through the splendid Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II, Milan's refined drawing room inaugurated in 1867. This elegant covered passage with its majestic iron and glass dome connects Piazza Duomo to Piazza della Scala, offering a unique experience among prestigious boutiques, historic caf√©s and exquisite mosaics. The architecture designed by Giuseppe Mengoni is a symbol of nineteenth-century Milanese ambition.

Explore the Museo del Novecento in the Palazzo dell'Arengario, a treasure trove of over 400 masterpieces of twentieth-century Italian art. From the celebrated Quarto Stato by Pellizza da Volpedo to works by Boccioni, Modigliani and Fontana, the chronological route guides you through Futurism, Metaphysical Art and Conceptual Art. The hall dedicated to Lucio Fontana offers a breathtaking view of the Duomo through the large windows.

Admire Leonardo da Vinci's Last Supper, one of the most famous paintings in the world housed in the refectory of Santa Maria delle Grazie. Created between 1494 and 1498 using an innovative technique, this depiction of the Last Supper reveals Leonardo's genius in its dramatic composition and the psychological depth of the figures. A deeply moving experience that requires advance booking.

Discover the Pinacoteca di Brera, one of Italy's most prestigious museums founded in 1776. The collection includes absolute masterpieces such as Caravaggio's Supper at Emmaus, Mantegna's Dead Christ, Piero della Francesca's Brera Altarpiece and Raphael's Marriage of the Virgin. Hayez's celebrated Kiss is the icon of Italian Romanticism.

Immerse yourself in the atmosphere of the Church of San Maurizio al Monastero Maggiore, known as Milan's Sistine Chapel. The vivid frescoes extend across no fewer than 4,000 square metres and are the work of the greatest masters of sixteenth-century Lombard painting, including Bernardino Luini. The plain fa√ßade on Corso Magenta conceals an interior of astonishing beauty.

activities.text: Stroll along the romantic Navigli, the ancient canal system designed in part by Leonardo da Vinci to connect Milan to the lakes and the sea. The recently renovated Darsena offers picturesque views, artisan workshops and a uniquely bohemian atmosphere in the heart of the city.

Explore the Castello Sforzesco, one of Europe's largest fortresses housing priceless treasures including Michelangelo's Piet√† Rondanini and Leonardo's frescoes. Behind it stretches the Parco Sempione, the city's green lung and the perfect setting for a relaxing walk to the Arch of Peace.

visits.text: Admire the Como Cathedral, a splendid church blending Gothic and Renaissance elements in the heart of the city. Built from 1396 and completed in the eighteenth century with the majestic dome designed by Filippo Juvarra, it is one of Lombardy's most important religious monuments. The richly decorated fa√ßade and solemn interiors bear witness to centuries of devotion and art.

Visit the Tempio Voltiano, an elegant Neoclassical museum dedicated to Alessandro Volta, Como's illustrious citizen and inventor of the electric battery. Set on the lakefront in a panoramic position, the museum houses original scientific instruments and documents tracing the revolutionary discoveries of the scientist who changed the course of history.

Ride the funicular up to Brunate, the balcony of the Alps offering breathtaking panoramas of the lake and the Alpine chain. This charming village at 720 metres altitude is reachable in just 7 minutes of scenic travel and rewards visitors with unforgettable views, particularly captivating at sunset.

activities.text: Stroll along the Como lakefront, an elegant promenade lined with historic villas, lush gardens and panoramic caf√©s. The crystal-clear waters of the Lario and the mountain profiles create a setting of incomparable beauty that has inspired poets and artists through the ages.

visits.text: Explore Punta Spartivento, the panoramic point where Lake Como divides into two branches creating its characteristic Y shape. From this legendary promontory you can admire a breathtaking view immortalised by Alessandro Manzoni in The Betrothed, with the mountains reflected in the crystal-clear waters.

Visit the Church of San Giacomo, a gem of Romanesque-Lombard art built in the twelfth century using the characteristic grey stone of Moltrasio. Inside you can admire precious frescoes and sculptures from different historical periods, while the bell tower bears witness to the village's ancient defensive system.

Wander through the grounds of Villa Serbelloni, a magnificent garden of nearly 21 hectares stretching across a steep promontory. This historic residence, now owned by the Rockefeller Foundation, boasts 18 km of paths among rare plants and panoramic vistas that have enchanted distinguished guests over the centuries, including Leonardo da Vinci and Alessandro Manzoni.

Discover the Gardens of Villa Melzi d'Eril, a botanical paradise on the western lakefront created in the early nineteenth century by the noble Milanese family. Among exotic plants, ancient trees, antique statues and archaeological finds, you can admire the famous statue of Dante and Beatrice that inspired Franz Liszt to compose his Dante Sonata.

activities.text: Walk up the Salita Serbelloni, a picturesque stairway connecting the lakefront to the old town through boutiques and characteristic establishments. Once known as Il Fossato for its medieval defensive role, it now features a commemorative plaque to the composer Franz Liszt, who stayed at length in this enchanting village.

visits.text: Admire the Church of San Giorgio, a splendid example of thirteenth-century medieval Lombard architecture built on the foundations of an ancient Roman temple. The grey stone fa√ßade is dominated by a majestic bell tower, while inside the 1822 Baroque high altar and a precious cycle of frescoes stand out. The floor of fine black marble completes the elegance of this sacred place.

Explore Villa Monastero, an evocative sixteenth-century architectural complex that was once a Cistercian convent. Today it is one of the lake's main attractions with its house museum and extraordinary botanical gardens hosting hundreds of plant species from around the world, along a path winding beside the lakeshore.

Visit Villa Cipressi, an elegant late-Renaissance gem with terraces cascading down towards the lake. This historic complex offers romantic views and manicured gardens delivering unforgettable panoramas over the waters of the Lario and the surrounding mountains.

activities.text: Walk the Passeggiata degli Innamorati (Lovers' Walk), a romantic walkway of about 500 metres suspended on the cliff face above the lake. This arched structure, draped in climbing plants that burst into a riot of colour and fragrance in the warmer months, connects the landing stage to the colourful houses of the old town in a route of incomparable beauty.

Climb to the Castello di Vezio, an ancient fortress overlooking Varenna from above with spectacular views of the lake and surrounding villages. You can explore the gardens, the atmospheric underground passages and the square watchtower housing a permanent art exhibition.

visits.text: Stroll along the Menaggio lakefront, an elegant Belle √âpoque promenade lined with refined caf√©s and Art Nouveau palms. This golden ribbon facing the waters of the Lario offers picturesque views of historic villas such as Villa Mylius Vigoni and Villa Govone, with the majestic Alps as a natural backdrop.

Explore the old town of Menaggio, characterised by cobbled lanes and lively little squares where you can breathe an atmosphere of times gone by. The bell tower with its copper dome dominates the village, while the pastel-coloured fa√ßades of the traditional houses create an environment of rare lakeside elegance.

activities.text: Take advantage of Menaggio's strategic position as a gateway to the Val Sanagra and Monte Grona for panoramic hikes, or head to the Golf Club Menaggio e Cadenabbia, one of Italy's oldest founded in 1907, set in an Alpine landscape of extraordinary beauty.

visits.text: Explore the Grotte di Rescia, a fascinating system of natural cavities rich in stalactites and stalagmites bearing witness to millennia of geological activity. This underground spectacle offers a unique experience among limestone formations of bizarre and evocative shapes, wrapped in an atmosphere of mystery and natural wonder.

Visit the Church of San Vittore il Moro, the religious heart of the Porlezza community built in the seventeenth century over a pre-existing fifth-century structure. Inside you can admire the frescoes by Giulio Quaglio di Laino depicting episodes from the saint's life, a precious Baroque altar, eighteenth-century stuccowork and fine wooden sculptures.

Discover the Oratory of San Maurizio Martire, a small church set just outside the centre that still preserves its original layout. This gem of religious architecture is a precious testimony to local devotion through the centuries.

activities.text: Enjoy the Lombard shore of Lake Lugano, a body of water shared between Italy and Switzerland offering views of rare beauty. Porlezza is a renowned holiday resort prized for its crystal-clear waters, equipped beaches and relaxed atmosphere that draws visitors from all over Europe.

visits.text: Admire the Palazzo Verbania, an Art Nouveau architectural jewel built in the nineteenth century that regularly hosts art exhibitions and cultural events. This elegant historic building is the cultural heart of the town, bearing witness to the period of great prosperity Luino enjoyed as a major trading centre on Lake Maggiore.

Visit the Church of San Pietro, one of the most significant religious buildings in the old town preserving precious artistic testimonies of local devotion. Together with the Church of San Giuseppe, it forms the sacred heritage of this fascinating lakeside town.

Don't miss the famous Luino Market, one of the largest open-air markets in the area and among the oldest in Europe. Every Wednesday the town centre streets come alive with stalls offering local produce, handicrafts and gastronomic specialities, attracting visitors from across the region and nearby Switzerland.

activities.text: Stroll along the magnificent Luino lakefront, one of Lake Maggiore's most beautiful promenades winding between elegant historic buildings and lush green spaces. The view over the crystal-clear waters and surrounding mountains invites moments of pure relaxation and contemplation.

Venture onto the panoramic trails around Luino, such as the walk to Colmegna along the lake or the hike to Monte Bedea and the charming Laghetto di Moncucco, immersed in Alpine scenery of extraordinary beauty.

visits.text: Visit the prepositural Church of Saints Philip and James, known as the old church, a religious building dating from 1315 that is the historic spiritual heart of Laveno. Beside it stands the Church of Sant'Ambrogio, built in 1940 by architect Paolo Mezzanotte in a modern style, together forming the sacred heritage of this charming lakeside town.

Discover Villa De Angeli Frua, an elegant eighteenth-century residence donated to the municipality and now home to the public library. The magnificent Parco delle Terrazze surrounding it offers breathtaking views of Lake Maggiore, with an evocative entrance tunnel that in spring is draped in blooming wisteria, creating a fairy-tale setting.

Ride the cable car up to Poggio Sant'Elsa for a privileged perspective of Lake Maggiore. This panoramic excursion offers spectacular views of the blue lake waters, the Borromean Islands in the distance and the Alpine skyline, delivering an unforgettable experience for nature and photography lovers.

activities.text: Stroll along the Laveno lakefront, one of Lake Maggiore's most evocative promenades offering views of the town, Stresa on the opposite shore and the famous Borromean Islands. From here ferries depart for Verbania, giving you the chance to explore both sides of the lake.

visits.text: Take a motorboat to the Island of San Giulio, a vision of pure poetry floating on the lake waters. Legend has it that in the fourth century the Greek holy traveller Giulio drove out a serpent that ruled the island. Walk the Via del Silenzio, a ten-minute loop dotted with meditative signs inviting reflection and introspection.

Climb the Salita della Motta, a picturesque cobbled lane lined with frescoed houses leading to the Church of Santa Maria Assunta. From this elevated point you can admire one of the lake's most evocative panoramas, with the Island of San Giulio seemingly floating on the crystal-clear waters.

Visit the small Church of San Rocco on the main street, a hidden gem that wins you over with its welcoming and spiritual atmosphere. Beside it stands the Palazzo Comunale with its wonderful flower garden overlooking the lake, a corner of paradise in the heart of the village.

Explore the Sacro Monte di Orta, a UNESCO World Heritage Site rising on the hill above the village. This sixteenth- to seventeenth-century devotional complex comprises twenty frescoed chapels dedicated to the life of Saint Francis of Assisi, set in an ancient wood with spectacular views of the lake and island.

activities.text: Wander through the cobbled lanes to Piazza Motta, the beating heart of the village overlooked by the sixteenth-century Palazzotto with its elegant arcades. From here public motorboats depart for the Island of San Giulio, offering unforgettable photographic vistas from the very moment of boarding.

Treat yourself to a lakeside stroll admiring the ancient frescoed palaces and breathing in the romantic atmosphere that also captivated Nietzsche, who arrived here almost by chance and was left spellbound by the beauty of the place. Villa Crespi, a Moorish-style masterpiece, is home to Antonino Cannavacciuolo's celebrated Michelin-starred restaurant.

visits.text: Explore Isola Bella, the jewel of the Borromean Islands housing the splendid Palazzo Borromeo, a perfectly preserved noble residence with precious paintings, tapestries and antique furnishings. The magnificent Borromean Gardens, created in the seventeenth century in pure Italian Baroque style, cascade over ten terraces towards the lake with an extraordinary variety of floral species and monumental statues.

Visit Isola Madre, the largest and most evocative of the Borromean Islands, wrapped in a quiet, suspended atmosphere. The sixteenth-century palace houses vast collections of period objects and a curious display of historic puppets, while the lush botanical garden is celebrated for its magnificent camellias, azaleas and exotic plants.

Admire Villa Pallavicino, an elegant nineteenth-century residence surrounded by a vast English-style garden hosting a fascinating zoological park. Among magnificent avenues lined with ancient trees and a wonderful botanical garden, you can encounter kangaroos, fallow deer, zebras and llamas in a beautifully kept natural setting, ideal for families with children.

Discover the Church of Sant'Ambrogio in the heart of Stresa, an elegant example of Neoclassical architecture with a Greek-cross plan completed in 1790. Inside lie the relics of San Vitaliano, a young Christian martyr venerated as protector of children, whose cult was introduced in 1835 following the transfer of his remains from the Roman catacombs.

activities.text: Ride the cable car to the summit of the Mottarone at 1,491 metres, from where you can admire one of the most spectacular panoramas in the Alps. The view stretches from Lake Maggiore to the Po Plain, from the peaks of Monte Rosa to the charming Giardino Botanico Alpinia, creating an unforgettable experience in every season.

Stroll along the romantic Stresa lakefront, lined with magnificent noble villas, exclusive historic hotels and manicured gardens lapped by the waters of Lake Maggiore. From here boats depart for the enchanting Borromean Islands and the extraordinary panorama of the Alps reflected in the lake.

visits.text: Lose yourself in the magnificent Botanical Gardens of Villa Taranto, twenty hectares of pure wonder on the shores of Lake Maggiore. Created by Scottish Captain McEacharn from 1931, these enchanting English-style gardens feature labyrinths of dahlias, water lily pools, valleys of rhododendrons, waterfalls and fountains in a place where care and love for nature are palpable at every turn.

Visit Villa San Remigio on the Colle della Castagnola, built in the early twentieth century by the poet and musician Marquis Silvio della Valle di Casanova and the painter Sofia Browne. Their dream garden is a true hymn to love, composed of several themed gardens overlooking the lake in a romantic atmosphere suspended in time.

Discover Villa Giulia and its park in the heart of Pallanza, built in the mid-nineteenth century by the Branca family, inventors of the famous Fernet. Now municipal property, it hosts temporary exhibitions while the park, always open and free, offers a privileged view of the lake and the picturesque village of Pallanza.

activities.text: Walk the lakeside promenade from Verbania to Pallanza, a pedestrian and cycle path of about 2 km offering breathtaking panoramas, ancient villas and dream palaces. An itinerary for daydreaming of a less hectic life on the lakefront, imagining yourself in an age of noble titles and grand balls.

Venture along the path to the Church of Buon Rimedio, an ancient mule track through jasmine-scented woods to a small eighteenth-century church. From this natural balcony overlooking Lake Maggiore you can enjoy breathtaking panoramic views and picnic at the equipped area with lakeside tables.

Explore the historic village of Pallanza with the Museo del Paesaggio housed in the Palazzo Viani Dugnani, rich in paintings, sculptures and archaeological finds. Then treat yourself to a stop at one of the lakeside terraces on the main square to savour the relaxed atmosphere of this enchanting corner of Piedmont.

visits.text: Ride the funicular up to Citt√† Alta, one of Italy's best-preserved medieval villages enclosed within the majestic Venetian Walls, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Wandering through the cobbled streets you'll discover centuries of history and Renaissance art in a timeless atmosphere that has captivated travellers of every era.

Admire Piazza Vecchia, the true civic drawing room overlooked by the Palazzo della Ragione, the Civic Tower (Campanone) and the Angelo Mai Library. Every evening the Campanone bell tolls one hundred times, just as in Venetian times when it signalled the closing of the city gates, evoking an atmosphere steeped in historical charm.

Visit the Basilica of Santa Maria Maggiore with its richly Baroque interiors adorned with tapestries and gilded stuccowork, and the adjacent Cappella Colleoni, a Renaissance masterpiece built as a mausoleum for the condottiere Bartolomeo Colleoni. The chapel's polychrome marble fa√ßades rank among the finest in Italy.

Explore the Accademia Carrara, one of Italy's most prestigious art galleries with over 1,800 paintings by artists such as Botticelli, Raphael, Mantegna, Titian and Canaletto. Directly opposite stands the GAMeC, the Gallery of Modern and Contemporary Art, creating a unique dialogue between tradition and modernity.

activities.text: Ride even higher on the San Vigilio Funicular to the Castle, crossing breathtaking landscapes with spectacular views of the city rooftops, medieval towers and the Lombard plain. From the castle ramparts you can enjoy one of the most beautiful sunsets in Lombardy.

Lose yourself in the Lorenzo Rota Botanical Garden, a small urban Eden of 2,400 sq m on the panoramic terraces of Citt√† Alta. From here you can admire a spectacular view of the city and surrounding mountains, with the Venetian Walls seeming to merge with the landscape in perfect harmony.

visits.text: Explore the Museo di Santa Giulia, an extraordinary monastic complex and the city's main museum housing treasures of exceptional historical and artistic importance. From the ninth-century Cross of Desiderius to the incredible frescoes of the Nuns' Choir, from the remains of ancient Roman Domus houses to the marvellous interiors of the Basilica of San Salvatore, it is part of the UNESCO site in the heart of Brescia.

Admire the Roman Archaeological Park, a UNESCO World Heritage Site comprising Piazza del Foro, the Capitolium with the hall dedicated to the Winged Victory, the Republican Sanctuary, the ancient theatre and the Roman Basilica. This extraordinary complex bears witness to the greatness of Brixia, one of northern Italy's most important cities in the Roman era.

Visit Piazza Loggia, the beating heart of Brescia characterised by a splendid blend of styles with a clear Venetian imprint. The Palazzo della Loggia, built between 1492 and 1570 with contributions from Palladio and Sansovino, dominates the square alongside the Clock Tower with its ancient astronomical clock.

Discover the Pinacoteca Tosio Martinengo, one of northern Italy's most important galleries with works by Raphael, Foppa, Moretto, Romanino, Lotto, Ceruti and Hayez. The route through 21 exhibition halls offers an intense journey from late Gothic to the early nineteenth century through the great Brescian Renaissance painting.

activities.text: Climb to Brescia Castle on the Colle Cidneo, a great fortress built between the fourteenth and sixteenth centuries in a commanding position over the city. A favourite destination for relaxing walks in the greenery, it houses the Luigi Marzoli Arms Museum and offers breathtaking views of the city and the Bergamo valleys.

Stroll through Piazza Paolo VI admiring the Duomo Vecchio, a rare example of Romanesque architecture with a circular plan, and the Duomo Nuovo completed in 1825. Then lose yourself in the ancient Carmine quarter with its evocative lanes, traditional taverns and bohemian atmosphere.

visits.text: Admire the Scaliger Castle, a majestic medieval fortress built after the mid-fourteenth century standing at the entrance to the old town. Surrounded by the crystal-clear waters of Lake Garda, the castle with its dock, courtyard and corridors evokes the poignant atmosphere of the Della Scala era, when it served as a strategic defensive position for the entire area.

Explore the Grotte di Catullo, the evocative remains of an ancient Roman villa from the first to second century AD in a spectacular position at the tip of the peninsula. Set among ancient olive trees and overlooking the lake panorama, the ruins are linked by popular tradition to the poet Catullus. The adjacent museum houses precious artefacts from Sirmione's and Lake Garda's history.

Visit the Church of San Pietro in Mavino, the oldest in the area dating from the eighth century AD. Nestled among olive trees on the hill of the same name, it offers an atmosphere of peace and silence with its Romanesque bell tower renovated in 1070 and evocative fourteenth-century frescoes, including a fine Madonna Enthroned with Child and Saints.

Discover the Palazzo Callas Exhibitions, dedicated to the memory of the Divine Maria Callas who chose Sirmione as her Italian refuge. Follow the evocative Callas Arie On Air trail, which through ten stops at the peninsula's most characteristic locations lets you relive the unique atmosphere of the most beautiful arias performed by the celebrated soprano.

activities.text: Relax at Spiaggia Giamaica, an exotic-feeling spot at the tip of Sirmione below the Grotte di Catullo. Formed of smooth white rocks polished by the waves, surrounded by crystal-clear waters and wild vegetation, it offers spectacular views towards the Rocca di Manerba and the northern part of the lake.

Treat yourself to a boat trip around the Sirmione peninsula to admire the harbour, Scaliger Castle, the Grotte di Catullo, the thermal facilities and Villa Callas from a unique perspective, interspersed with wonderful natural panoramas and lush Mediterranean vegetation.

Stroll through the old village from the Scaliger Castle to the Grotte di Catullo, immersing yourself in local history through evocative lanes, the remains of the Church of San Salvatore and Roman-era sites, with refreshing stops in the parks and characteristic establishments of the old town.

visits.text: Explore the Castle of Desenzano del Garda, an imposing fortress erected in the early Middle Ages probably on the remains of an ancient Roman castrum. Of the original construction, portions of walls and truncated corner towers survive; from the panoramic observatory at the top you can enjoy a spectacular view of Lake Garda that amply rewards the climb.

Visit the Cathedral of Santa Maria Maddalena, a splendid example of late Brescian Renaissance built between the late sixteenth and early seventeenth centuries. Inside it houses important works by Andrea Celesti, and in the Chapel of the Blessed Sacrament you can admire G.B. Tiepolo's celebrated Last Supper from 1738, a masterpiece of eighteenth-century Venetian painting.

Discover the Roman Villa, the most important testimony to the great late-antique villas of northern Italy. Built between the first and fourth centuries AD and accidentally discovered in 1921, it preserves over 240 sq m of extraordinary polychrome mosaics featuring cupids, maenads, satyrs and wild animals, bearing witness to the refinement of Roman life on the lake.

Admire the Giovanni Rambotti Archaeological Museum, rich in prehistoric finds from the Lake Garda area dating mainly from the Bronze Age. Among the treasures it houses is what is considered the oldest wooden plough in the world, a precious testimony to the first farming communities that inhabited these shores.

activities.text: Stroll through the picturesque Porto Vecchio, one of Desenzano's most evocative corners overlooked by the broad arcades of Palazzo Todeschini. The dock took shape in the days of the Venetian Republic; don't miss the curious Stone of the Unemployed from 1555, where town criers and those condemned for bankruptcy would stand.

visits.text: Explore the Fortress of Peschiera del Garda, an extraordinary example of military architecture enclosing the entire old town. Its walls, a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 2017, bear witness to centuries of history: from Roman fort to Scaliger stronghold, from sixteenth-century Venetian fortress to Habsburg citadel. Enter through the monumental Porta Verona or Porta Brescia to discover this defensive gem.

Visit the Sanctuary of the Madonna del Frassino, a splendid monumental church nestled in nature at the foot of the Lake Garda hills. Built between 1511 and 1514 on the spot where the Madonna appeared to the farmer Bartolomeo Broglia, the sanctuary kept by the Franciscan Friars Minor features a single nave and two marvellous frescoed chapels.

activities.text: Stroll along the Lungolago Mazzini, a wonderful lakeside promenade stretching about 700 metres from the old town to the Lido dei Cappuccini. This panoramic route, perfect at sunset, is lined with elegant establishments and offers spectacular views of the crystal-clear waters of Lake Garda.

Relax at the Lido Cappuccini, one of the lake's most popular bathing establishments where you can hire sun loungers and pedalos, swim in the clear waters and enjoy a refreshing break on the pebble beach, with lifeguard service and a restaurant right on the waterfront.

visits.text: Let yourself be enchanted by the Arena di Verona, a majestic Roman amphitheatre built in 30 AD and splendidly preserved. Originally capable of seating up to 30,000 spectators, today it is one of the world's most prestigious venues for open-air opera and concerts, where the perfect acoustics and magical atmosphere make every performance unforgettable.

Visit Juliet's House on Via Cappello, the iconic symbol of Shakespearean romance with its famous balcony and courtyard that have inspired the timeless love story. In the courtyard you can admire the bronze statue of Juliet by Nereo Costantini, which tradition says brings luck in love to those who touch it.

Explore Castelvecchio and the Ponte Scaligero, an imposing medieval fortress with a magnificent fortified bridge offering breathtaking views over the River Adige. The museum inside houses extraordinary collections of medieval and Renaissance art, sculptures, paintings and the city's ancient bells displayed across 29 unique rooms.

Admire the Basilica of San Zeno Maggiore, a masterpiece of Romanesque architecture built between 967 and 1398 AD. The intricate bronze doors, extraordinary frescoes and imposing altarpiece by Mantegna will take your breath away. According to tradition, the crypt is the place where Romeo and Juliet celebrated their secret marriage.

Discover the Roman Theatre, an ancient first-century BC theatre rising on a hill overlooking the city and the River Adige. In summer it hosts the Estate Teatrale Veronese with performances of drama, dance and music in a unique atmosphere where history and culture blend under the stars.

activities.text: Stroll through Piazza delle Erbe, the beating heart of Verona surrounded by colourful buildings, frescoed palaces and lively market stalls. At the centre of the square stands the fountain of Madonna Verona, while all around you can breathe the vibrant atmosphere of a city that has preserved its charm through the centuries.

Lose yourself in the Giardino Giusti, one of the finest Italian-style gardens in existence, with geometric flowerbeds, ancient cypresses, grottoes and panoramic terraces offering breathtaking views across all of Verona. This sixteenth-century Renaissance gem is the perfect spot for a refreshing pause immersed in beauty.

Cross the Ponte Pietra, the ancient Roman bridge linking the old town to the bohemian quarter of Veronetta. From here you'll enjoy enchanting views of the River Adige, the Roman Theatre and the hill of San Pietro, the perfect setting for a sunset stroll.

seo.h1_title: Grand Tour of the Italian Lakes: Milan to Verona in 17 Days
seo.intro_paragraph: Embark on an unforgettable journey through northern Italy, from vibrant Milan to romantic Verona. This 17-day itinerary takes you along Lakes Como, Maggiore and Garda, past sumptuous villas, extraordinary botanical gardens and art cities steeped in history. A trip that blends magnificent nature, UNESCO heritage and the Italian art of living.
seo.seo_hook: 17 dream days from Milan through the great lakes to Verona: the ultimate northern Italy road trip.
featured_list: Milan: the Duomo, Leonardo's Last Supper and the Navigli canals
Lake Como: Bellagio, Varenna and their legendary villas
Lake Maggiore: the Borromean Islands and Villa Taranto gardens
Orta San Giulio: the enchanted island and UNESCO Sacro Monte
Bergamo and Brescia: two gems of art and history
Lake Garda: Sirmione, Desenzano and Peschiera del Garda
Verona: the Roman Arena, Castelvecchio and Romeo and Juliet

places_taglines.IT::varenna: Romantic fishing village with sublime villas and the Lovers' Walk
places_taglines.IT::menaggio: Belle √âpoque promenade and gateway to Alpine hikes on Lake Como
places_taglines.IT::porlezza: Bridge between Lake Como and Lake Lugano, amid caves and crystal waters
places_taglines.IT::luino: Lake Maggiore gem famous for its centuries-old Wednesday market
places_taglines.IT::laveno-mombello: Privileged viewpoint over the Borromean Islands from Lake Maggiore's eastern shore
places_taglines.IT::orta-san-giulio: Medieval jewel on Lake Orta, with its mystical island and UNESCO Sacro Monte
places_taglines.IT::stresa: Gateway to the Borromean Islands and Alpine panoramas from the Mottarone
places_taglines.IT::verbania: Botanical paradise on Lake Maggiore, between Villa Taranto and the charm of Pallanza
places_taglines.IT::bergamo: Medieval upper town ringed by Venetian walls, a UNESCO World Heritage Site
places_taglines.IT::brescia: The Lioness of Italy, between Roman ruins and Renaissance masterpieces
places_taglines.IT::sirmione: Enchanted peninsula on Lake Garda, between Scaliger castle and Roman ruins
places_taglines.IT::desenzano-del-garda: Lively Lake Garda port, rich in Roman mosaics and Venetian history
places_taglines.IT::peschiera-del-garda: UNESCO star-shaped fortress at the outlet of Lake Garda, blending history and beaches
places_taglines.IT::verona: City of Romeo and Juliet, between Roman arenas and medieval palaces on the Adige

seo.h1_title: Italian Lakes Majesty: Lake Como, Lake Garda & Alpine Mountain Scenery
seo.intro_paragraph: Glide along Lake Como between mountains and villas, then explore the luminous expanse of Lake Garda. Stop at Lake Orta and the island of San Giulio, a monastic haven set upon the water. Stresa connects these alpine landscapes in gentle timeless harmony.
seo.seo_hook: Alpine peaks crowning crystal waters, villas framing mountain panoramas. Italian lakes, elegance and serene romance.

seo.h1_title: Le Marche's Hilltop Towns: Urbino, Ascoli Piceno & Sibillini Mountains
seo.intro_paragraph: Cross Gradara and its fortress facing the Adriatic, then discover Offida between lace and workshops. Gain height at Cingoli, follow Montefiore dell'Aso's lanes and reach Mercatello sul Metauro along the valley. The Marche offers a discreet perched Italy, where each village keeps its voice and gestures.
seo.seo_hook: Fortresses crowning hills, ceramic workshops carrying on their craft, traditions alive. Le Marche, hilltop villages and secrets.

seo.h1_title: Northern to Central Italy: Art Cities, Heritage Sites and Culinary Passion
seo.intro_paragraph: Feel Milan's creative drive, reach Genoa's historic port and follow the coast to La Spezia. Admire Pisa's singular balance, dive into Florence's artistic effervescence and cross medieval hills before reaching Rome, majestic synthesis of eternal Italy.
seo.seo_hook: Fashion animating northern cities, Renaissance frescoes glowing with timeless gold. A journey through Italy, two weeks of beauty.

seo.h1_title: Italian Lakes and Dolomites: Alpine Splendor and Mountain Passes
seo.intro_paragraph: Stroll along Lake Como's elegant shores between villas and water reflections, then glide toward the vastness of Lake Garda. Stop at Iseo and Sirmione before climbing toward the Dolomites and Cortina d'Ampezzo. Venice concludes this journey between lagoon, stone and silence.
seo.seo_hook: Alpine peaks piercing clouds, lakes reflecting mountain majesty. Italian lakes and Dolomites, spectacular harmony.

Visit to Castello del Buonconsiglio, former residence of the prince-bishops, now an art and history museum.
